title: (x) C-Tec 'Darker' 1997 CD cover - Palatino {Pieter}
content:
[http://www.discogs.com/image/R-65118-1159890045.jpeg](http://web.archive.org/web/20071018175922/http:/www.discogs.com/image/R-65118-1159890045.jpeg "http://www.discogs.com/image/R-65118-1159890045.jpeg")

Hi. I’ve been trying to find this typeface forever — already tried _Identifont_ and _WhatTheFont_ with no joy… Anyone have any ideas?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [c-tec.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20071018175922/http:/typophile.com/files/c-tec.jpg) | 5.7 KB |
| [darker.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20071018175922/http:/typophile.com/files/darker.jpg) | 4.13 KB |

 [‹ Vimeo logo?](http://web.archive.org/web/20071018175922/http:/typophile.com/node/31680 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Hicksdesign.co.uk Bauhaus-styl geometric sans - House Chalet {Addison Hall} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071018175922/http:/typophile.com/node/31654 "Go to next forum topic")
author: safetycopy

comments.content:
I think it’s no font but just flipped C’s and a flipped three...  
Pieter

Hi Pieter. Thanks for the quick reply.

The flipped letter idea never even crossed my mind, but now you’ve pointed it out, it seems obvious! I’ve added an image of the ’darker’ text, which supports your idea further.

Any idea what the font might be, prior to ‘flipping operations’?

I think they used Palatino for the trick.  
 [http://www.linotype.com/12523/palatinoroman-font.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20071018175922/http:/www.linotype.com/12523/palatinoroman-font.html "http://www.linotype.com/12523/palatinoroman-font.html")

Pieter
Well — that’ certainly close enough for me… Thanks!
